Jubilee was a welcome celebration of British culture

28/06/2022

Quintessentially British affair unites the nation, despite generational divides and Queen's absence

Image by Garry Knight

By Molli Tyldesley

No matter your views on theÂ monarch, the Queenâ€™s Platinum Jubilee celebrations of theÂ long weekend at the beginning of JuneÂ were all encompassing. They engulfedÂ British society and the public into celebrating all things British. WithoutÂ even trying you likely felt the patriotism throughout the weekend with shopÂ windows, street bunting and flags of theÂ Union Jack and the Queen everywhere.

The television and radio were noÂ escape from the celebrations, with theÂ BBC providing extensive coverage of the numerous official events to celebrate theÂ Queenâ€™s 70 years on the throne. The celebration was all consumed by popularÂ culture and also British society.Â All over the country, the Queenâ€™sÂ Platinum Jubilee was an excuse to celebrate with friends and families, something which was important followingÂ the various restricted periods duringÂ the Covid-19 pandemic. Streets acrossÂ the country were closed for street celebrations, British themed parties wereÂ hosted, and drinks were drunk, so overall it seemed like the perfect excuse forÂ a party.

Even if the royal family are not everyone's cup of tea, unless you hibernated over the weekend, it was likely thatÂ everyone got involved.Â For me personally, the entire weekend made meÂ appreciate the royal family just a littleÂ bit more. The celebrations allowed meÂ to recognise that there was somethingÂ quite unifying and nice about everyoneÂ celebrating together. There was a realÂ sense of community running throughout the weekend's celebrations.

The extent to which the entireÂ country erupted in Jubilee celebrationsÂ is significant and poses the question ofÂ what the future will hold for the royalÂ family.Â It is undeniable that the Queen isÂ a well-liked monarch who, reigning forÂ 70 years, has been Head of State for theÂ majority of the publicâ€™s entire lifetimes,Â thus she has been a constant figure ofÂ security in times of hardship and prosperity.

The Queen is by far the most popular member of the Royal Family, withÂ 45 percent of Britons voting for her asÂ such in an Ipsos survey conducted thisÂ year.Â However, the adoration for theÂ Queen does not necessarily extend toÂ the rest of the Royal Family. Further,Â YouGov discovered that overall 62 percent of the general population believeÂ that the monarchy is a good thingÂ although attitudes are unlikely to remain the same for the future Head ofÂ State; it will be a tough act to followÂ for the future Kings.

Will the patriotism and extensive celebrations for the QueenÂ continue for the future Kings of theÂ United Kingdom? Prince Charles,Â the next heir to the throne, is by noÂ means as openly trusted and respectedÂ as the Queen, with only 49 percent believing he will do a good job as King.Â In order to maintain the popularity of the monarch, he will have to winÂ over the hearts of the country. PrinceÂ William, on the other hand, is alreadyÂ more popular with 74 percent of theÂ population having faith in him as KingÂ according to Ipsos, 2022.

Additionally, there is also a generational divide when it comes to theÂ views of Britain on the monarch. TheÂ love and admiration for the Queen isÂ most commonly expressed by the olderÂ generation in Britain.Â In light of the Platinum Jubilee,Â YouGov conducted a survey investigating Britonâ€™s views of the monarch.Â The older generation of Britons areÂ evidently much fonder of the QueenÂ than the younger generations, with 77Â percent older than 65 believing thatÂ Britain should continue to have a monarch, whilst comparably, this was onlyÂ believed by 33 percent aged 18-24. ThisÂ poses the question of whether an eventÂ so all consuming in celebration of theÂ monarchy will happen to the same extent again?

With little faith being instilled inÂ Prince Charles and approval ratingsÂ of the monarch declining among theÂ younger generation, it could suggestÂ that the role of the monarch in BritainÂ is becoming increasingly unstable. It isÂ unlikely that we will experience a celebration of the monarch to this extentÂ again in our lifetimes and we certainlyÂ wonâ€™t celebrate another monarch's Platinum Jubilee.

Nevertheless, the absence of theÂ Queen from some of her celebrationsÂ meant that the focus of many of the festivities was on the heir Prince CharlesÂ and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. This in turn might have alreadyÂ started to win over public opinion...Â In fact, could this Jubilee celebration have even won over some of theÂ younger population to the value of theÂ monarchy and be a stepping stone towards greater support for future monarchs?

The all encompassing nature of theÂ Platinum Jubilee festivities immersedÂ all aspects of society into celebrations.Â It was difficult not to get involved andÂ thus, I couldnâ€™t help but feel somewhatÂ patriotic even whilst watching the questionable choice of icons performing atÂ Buckingham Palace. The long weekendÂ was enjoyed by all, with an extra twoÂ days off work, so the Platinum JubileeÂ was somewhat exploited as an excuseÂ for celebration.

Yet, at the same time, not being aÂ Royalist myself, it made me appreciateÂ that there is something quite nice aboutÂ the monarchy on a surface level as a fundamental part of British culture. The actÂ of drinking tea and eating scones withÂ cream and jam is indeed quite a comforting, unique, and quintessentiallyÂ British way to celebrate.Â I for one would be happy for another excuse to celebrate in the future.
